user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 is: A project shall not contain dead code.
Any operation that is executed but whose removal would not affect program behaviour constitutes dead code. Notes:
1. The behaviour of an embedded sytem is often determined not just by the nature of its actions, but also by the time at which they occur.
2. unreachable code is not dead code, as it cannot be executed.
3.Initialization is not the same as an assignment operation and is therfore not a candidate for dead code.
</misra_rule>

Another agent reported that the target code violated the Rule 2.2.
Here is the comment from the agent.
<violation scenario>
If OS_STATIC_SYMTABLE_SOURCE (i.e. OS_STATIC_SYMBOL_TABLE) is defined as a non-NULL pointer to a statically allocated, sentinel-terminated array (entries end with Name == NULL), then StaticSym is never set to NULL by the loop increments. The loop therefore always relies on the internal sentinel (StaticSym->Name == NULL) to break out; the test while (StaticSym != NULL) is executed each iteration but always true and can be removed without changing program behaviour. In that build/configuration the comparison is an executed operation whose removal would not affect behaviour, which meets the definition of dead code in MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2.
</violation scenario>

Your job is to insert logging code to capture the control flow and state information of the program.
Insert logging code so that other agents can reproduce and get evidence for the violation scenario.
<response format>
- test_code: a modified OS_ModuleLoad_Static code that contains useful probe functions that print useful logs to a file "/tmp/logs/1118.txt". The logs should contain the control path and state information of the violation scenario. If test code is not required to validate the scenario, you can leave this blank.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ModuleLoad_Static:
```c
int32 OS_ModuleLoad_Static(const char *ModuleName)
{
    int32                      return_code = OS_ERR_NAME_NOT_FOUND;
    OS_static_symbol_record_t *StaticSym   = OS_STATIC_SYMTABLE_SOURCE;

    while (StaticSym != NULL)
    {
        if (StaticSym->Name == NULL)
        {
            /* end of list  */
            break;
        }
        if (StaticSym->Module != NULL && strcmp(StaticSym->Module, ModuleName) == 0)
        {
            /* found matching module name */
            return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
            break;
        }

        ++StaticSym;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>

<instruction>

Please provide the modified OS_ModuleLoad_Static code.

The information below explains how I’ll use the function you provide. Please use it as a reference when generating code.
1. Replacement
  - I will parse your function and replace the original OS_ModuleLoad_Static with it.
  - Your function must have the exact same signature as OS_ModuleLoad_Static.
  - It must be a complete, self-contained definition; (no omissions, placeholders (e.g., "..."), or comments indicating skipped/omitted logic.)
2. Logging / reachability
  - I will run a test suite that is guaranteed to call OS_ModuleLoad_Static to check logs.
  - Your function MUST preserve the original logic of OS_ModuleLoad_Static as much as possible.
  - The log output must not be empty. Even if you are verifying dead code, OS_ModuleLoad_Static will be reached; insert a minimal probe/log to demonstrate that the target function was entered.
3. Coverage
  - I will run the same test suite to measure coverage.
  - Test outcomes must match those of the original code.
  - If reproducing the rule violation necessarily causes a crash (e.g., the violation inherently triggers a crash), that is acceptable; otherwise, your function should not crash under the existing test suite so coverage can be measured.
4. Test code constraints
  - The test code MUST preserve the original logic of OS_ModuleLoad_Static as much as possible.
  - DO NOT introduce new violations to demonstrate your scenario.
  - The test code MUST be compilable and executable.
  - The test code MUST include line breaks.
  - You MUST NOT define the main function.
  - You MUST NOT define macros.
  - You MUST NOT REDEFINE any existing identifiers, such as macros, static/global variables, or functions.
  - Do not break string literals or include stray/unmatched double quotes; the code must parse cleanly with no quote-related errors.

These are common mistakes of generated codes. Do not make these mistakes:
- Redefining existing functions, variables, types, or macros.
- Broken string literals or unmatched quotes.
- Invoking undeclared function.
- Using undeclared member in a struct.
- Invoking functions with wrong parameter type.

</instruction>
